messages.title: Protecting our NHS
messages.content: Labour created the NHS, but under Theresa May’s government it is in crisis. Hospitals are understaffed, GPs are difficult to recruit and waiting lists are longer. Labour will give the NHS the resources it needs to serve our country. We will ensure nurses do not have to pay for their training and will increase investment in the mental and physical health. A Labour government will also mount a major programme to improve the health and wellbeing of every child in the country. This will include increasing the Index of Child Health to measure progress against international standards; legally requiring all Government departments to have a child health strategy to set out how they will support the UK’s ambition to make our children healthier than previous generations. We will also make sure nurses and health visitors to make house calls and give families the healthcare they are entitled to. A Labour Government would secure extra funding for Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services and support for counseling in every school.

messages.title: Keeping our communities safe
messages.content: David’s role on the City Council is overseeing the council’s work with children. He is presenting Ruddington foster carers Andrea and Graham Hardy and Carol Jarvis MBE for their service. But resources in Children’s and Adults’ services are tight, and using fosterers like Andrea and Carol to look after vulnerable children is only part of fostering care. We need compassionate care workers to step up and look after the kids in their homes, to step into chaotic homes where they can live by 15 minute appointments. Labour will end zero hour contracts and give care workers more security. We also need a strong police force to keep our communities safe from crime. We will also take 10,000 new officers over the past seven years and investigate new technology.

messages.title: A Brexit that protects British jobs
messages.content: 57% of Rushcliffe residents voted to remain last June, but the country voted differently and so we will be leaving the EU. However, we must negotiate a deal which is as good as it can be for our economy. We need to retain our key relationships with other European countries, particularly on issues like travel for students. European citizens living and working in the UK must not be used as bargaining chips for Mrs May.

messages.title: Budget cuts hit Rushcliffe Schools
messages.content: The Tory Government’s ‘Fairer Funding’ proposals would hit Rushcliffe schools with massive cuts. South Notts Academy alone will have to save hundreds of thousands of pounds from their budgets. These budget cuts will mean drastic cuts to all Rushcliffe Schools – losing resources, staff and extra students support. West Bridgford will lose £605 per pupil, which comes to £1 million. Edwalton will lose £590 per pupil, Abbey Gate Academy will lose £1 million. Rushcliffe School will lose £742 per pupil.
